content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC)</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/31268" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle/> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/31268</id> <updated>2015-03-06T08:32:59Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-06T08:32:59Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Early Development of Graphene Electronics</title> <link href="http://hdl.handle.net/1853/31270" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>de Heer, Walt A.</name> </author> <id>http://hdl.handle.net/1853/31270</id> <updated>2009-12-05T09:36:47Z</updated> <published>2009-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Early Development of Graphene Electronics de Heer, Walt A. Graphene has recently emerged as a material likely to complement or eventually succeed silicon in electronics. From 2001 to 2004, groundbreaking research was pursued behind the scenes at Georgia Tech; various directions were explored, including exfoliation techniques and CVD growth, but epitaxial graphene on silicon carbide emerged as the most viable route. This document provides archival information that may otherwise be difficult to obtain, including two proposals on file with the NSF, submitted in 2001 and 2003, and the first graphene patent, filed in 2003. The 2001 document proposes much of the graphene research carried out during this decade, and the 2003 proposal includes the data that was eventually published in J. Phys. Chem. B in Dec. 2004. Note: Some personal information has been removed; original documents are available upon request. </summary> <dc:date>2009-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> <dc:creator>de Heer, Walt A.</dc:creator> <dc:description>Graphene has recently emerged as a material likely to complement or eventually succeed silicon in electronics. From 2001 to 2004, groundbreaking research was pursued behind the scenes at Georgia Tech; various directions were explored, including exfoliation techniques and CVD growth, but epitaxial graphene on silicon carbide emerged as the most viable route. This document provides archival information that may otherwise be difficult to obtain, including two proposals on file with the NSF, submitted in 2001 and 2003, and the first graphene patent, filed in 2003. The 2001 document proposes much of the graphene research carried out during this decade, and the 2003 proposal includes the data that was eventually published in J. Phys. Chem. B in Dec. 2004.</dc:description> </entry> </feed>
